name: Malahide Castle and Gardens
tagline: 800 years of history in one of Ireland's most iconic medieval castles
significance: One of Ireland's oldest castles, home to the Talbot family for over 800 years
foundedBy: Richard Talbot received Malahide for his services to the crown in 1185

description.short: Step back in time and explore the magnificent Malahide Castle, home to the Talbot family for over 800 years. Discover opulent state rooms, exquisite art collections, and fascinating tales of the past set within 260 acres of parkland.
description.full: Malahide Castle, parts of which date to the 12th century, stands as one of Ireland's most iconic medieval landmarks, located just 14 minutes from Dublin Airport in the picturesque seaside village of Malahide. From 1185 onwards, the Talbot family became intertwined with Malahide's history and development. The earliest believed stone fortress at Malahide was an Anglo-Norman tower house. From the 12th century onwards, this stronghold was continually expanded by the Talbot family. Rooms were modified, fortifications developed and many embellishments to the interior were added until the castle took on its current form. The castle is filled with a rich family history and a unique collection of artwork, furniture and architecture compiled over the eight centuries of the Talbots tenure. With many rooms remaining the same as when the final Baron de Malahide lived in the Castle, visitors can step back 800 years in time to explore opulent state rooms including the Oak Room, drawing room, the Great Hall and library. The estate features over 260 acres of remaining parkland (the Malahide Demesne Regional Park), meticulously landscaped botanic gardens, Ireland's only exotic Butterfly House, and a magical Fairy Trail perfect for families.
description.history: Richard Talbot received Malahide for his services to the crown in 1185, beginning an extraordinary 800-year association between the Talbot family and the castle. The earliest stone fortress was an Anglo-Norman tower house dating to the 12th century. Over the following centuries, the Talbot family continually expanded and modified the castle, adding rooms, developing fortifications, and creating many interior embellishments. The castle served as the family seat through medieval times, the Tudor period, the Cromwellian era, and into the modern age. Many rooms remain exactly as they were when the final Baron de Malahide lived in the castle. The Talbot family sold the property to the Irish State in 1975, who have since worked to preserve its magnificent beauty and history. Today it stands as one of Ireland's most important medieval heritage sites.
description.architecture: Malahide Castle showcases the evolution of Irish castle architecture from medieval times through to the Georgian era. The original 12th-century Anglo-Norman tower house forms the core, around which successive generations added Gothic revival elements, Tudor features, and Georgian embellishments. The castle features impressive state rooms including the Oak Room with its ornate wood paneling, the Great Hall with medieval ambiance, an elegant drawing room, and a well-stocked library. The interior boasts exquisite art collections including portraits of the Talbot family spanning generations, antique furnishings, and architectural details from various periods. The castle's multiple towers overlook a courtyard and are surrounded by 260 acres of parkland featuring formal gardens, woodland walks, and stunning coastal views.
description.culturalSignificance: Malahide Castle represents one of the longest continuous family occupancies of any castle in Ireland, with the Talbot family residing there for over 800 years. It serves as a living museum showcasing Irish aristocratic life from medieval times through to the 20th century. The castle's art collections, furnishings, and architecture provide invaluable insights into Irish history, culture, and craftsmanship. As one of Ireland's most visited heritage sites, it plays a crucial role in preserving and presenting Irish medieval history to both domestic and international visitors. The castle has also become a cultural venue for events, education programs, and serves as a symbol of Ireland's rich architectural heritage.

directions.general: Malahide Castle is located just 10 minutes from Dublin Airport and 25 minutes from Dublin city centre in the picturesque coastal village of Malahide
directions.byCar: From Dublin city: Take the M1 or coastal route north. Follow signs to Malahide village. Ample free parking available on-site with 7 coach bays for tour groups. From Dublin Airport: 14-minute drive via R132
directions.byBus: Dublin Bus routes 32 and 42 connect Dublin city center with Malahide village. Route 102 operates direct from Dublin Airport to Malahide village. Castle is approximately 10-minute walk from village
directions.byTrain: DART (Dublin Area Rapid Transit) to Malahide Station from various Dublin city centre stations. Castle is approximately 10-minute walk from Malahide DART station
directions.parking: Ample free parking on-site including designated disabled parking spaces and 7 coach bays for group tours

seasonal.notes: Castle, Gardens, Butterfly House, and Fairy Trail all open from 9:30am

admissionPrices.notes: Child rate applies to ages 4-17 years. Senior rate for 65+. Student rate with valid ID. Family tickets available for 2 adults + 2 children or 2 adults + 3 children. Prices current as of 2025 but may change - check website for latest pricing

included: Guided tour of main state rooms
tourOptions.notes: Audio guides available in Irish, French, German, Spanish, Italian, Russian and Mandarin
Special evening experience - 6pm start. Seasonal availability

visitingInformation.averageVisitDuration: 2-3 hours minimum recommended to fully enjoy all attractions
visitingInformation.adviceForVisitors: Pre-booking tickets is highly recommended, especially during peak season and for larger groups. Advance booking guarantees entry and may reduce queuing time. Comfortable walking shoes recommended for exploring the extensive grounds. Allow minimum 2 hours to fully experience castle and gardens. Tour tickets are non-refundable but can be edited within 48-hour window. Bicycles and scooters not permitted in gardens or on Fairy Trail.

highlights: Magnificent medieval castle with Anglo-Norman tower house core
Opulent state rooms (Oak Room, Great Hall, Drawing Room, Library)
Exquisite art collections and antique furnishings
World-renowned Botanic Gardens with rare and exotic plant species
Magical Fairy Trail for children and families
Free admission to parkland (Malahide Demesne Regional Park)
9-hole golf course and 18-hole pitch and putt on grounds
Malahide Cricket Club on historic grounds

accessibility.notes: Malahide Castle and Gardens are generally wheelchair accessible with ramps, lifts, and adapted restrooms. Due to historic nature of buildings, some areas may have limited accessibility. Visitor Centre fully accessible. Contact reservations team for specific accessibility concerns: reservations@malahidecastleandgardens.ie
restrictions: Some historic areas have limited access
No bicycles or scooters in gardens or Fairy Trail

uniqueSellingPoints: One of Ireland's oldest castles dating to 1185
Longest continuous family occupancy - Talbot family for 800+ years
Only 14 minutes from Dublin Airport - perfect for day trips
Accessible by DART from Dublin city centre (30-35 minutes)
Ireland's only exotic Butterfly House with hundreds of tropical species
260 acres of stunning parkland free to explore
Rooms preserved exactly as when final Baron de Malahide lived there
Family-friendly with Fairy Trail, Butterfly House, and playgrounds
Venue hire available for weddings and corporate events
Annual membership passes for unlimited visits
